awd_titl_txt: Travel Support for Broadening Participation of Researchers in the REMADE Institute Circular Economy Tech Summit and Conference; Washington, DC; 20-21 March 2023
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides students and young faculty from underrepresented or underserved groups in STEM education with travel support to attend and participate in the REMADE Institute Circular Economy Tech Summit and Conference. REMADE’s mission is to foster manufacturing technologies that reduce embodied energy and decrease emissions. The conference aims to provide a forum to share leading-edge research on technologies that accelerate the US's transition to a Circular Economy. In addition, the conference offers participants an opportunity to showcase their scientific accomplishments, interact with peers and colleagues from academia, government labs, and industry, extend their network, and foster new collaborations within the broader advanced manufacturing community. Consistent with NSF's goal to broaden the participation of groups underrepresented in science and engineering, the REMADE Institute preferentially allocates travel funds to underrepresented minorities, women, and persons with disabilities. This approach promotes greater diversity in STEM fields and benefits the nation by educating and training a skilled workforce better prepared to provide transformative solutions to overcome challenges in their chosen fields. The conference meets the national priorities of advancing environmental quality and achieving diversity, equity and inclusion.

The REMADE Institute anticipates conference attendance benefits the students and young faculty's professional, scientific and technical development. The conference provides attendees with a broader view of the material lifecycle and discusses the different product lifecycle stages  - design, manufacturing, remanufacturing, recycling and upcycling -  that are critical to understanding the achievement of a circular economy. Attendees also gain a system-level perspective necessary to identify cross-cutting research opportunities. The conference, organized into different technology tracks, includes talks by leading domestic and international speakers discussing their latest research on topics such as building a sustainable circular economy, systems analysis, design for circularity, pathways to achieve net-zero emissions in manufacturing and materials production, remanufacturing, and recycling. In addition, students and young faculty are able to enhance their communication skills through oral and poster presentations and in-depth discussions of their work with their peers. This interactive experience significantly broadens the education and training of students and young faculty from underrepresented groups, increase their enthusiasm for the research topic, acquaint them with expectations for scientific careers, and expose them to new approaches and opportunities for innovative research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Outcome Report – Award #2309468 

Title: NSF Funding to Support Broadening Participation of Researchers in the REMADE Institute Inaugural Circular Economy Tech Summit and Conference.

P.I.: Dr. Nabil Nasr, CEO of the REMADE Institute

Associate Provost Academic Affairs and Director of Golisano Institute for Sustainability, Rochester Institute of Technology

 

The REMADE Institute (REMADE), in strategic partnership with the Ellen MacArthur Foundation and with support from the U.S. Department of Energy’s Office of Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy (EERE), successfully convened the inaugural Circular Economy Technology Summit and Conference. Held at the National Academy of Sciences Building in Washington, D.C., from March 20–21, 2023, this event brought together a distinguished cohort of international experts from academia, national laboratories, trade associations, U.S. industry, and government agencies.

The intellectual merit of this conference is that it integrates a focus on the materials lifecycle stages (design, manufacturing, remanufacturing, and recycling) with a system-level perspective designed to identify cross-cutting research opportunities. The conference boasted an impressive array of 59 peer-reviewed research papers and over 25 R&D project posters. Track topics included AI and Machine Learning, Mechanical and Chemical Recycling, Pathways to Net Zero Emissions, Systems Analysis, and the Circular Economy. 

The broader impact of the conference is dissemination of foundational knowledge to support the development of technologies  that will accelerate sustainable manufacturing and the U.S. transition to a Circular Economy. Over 300 people attended the 2-day event, including 25 individuals supported by a National Science Foundation grant to broaden participation of researchers who might not otherwise be able to attend this conference.   The awardees were selected from a pool of applicants based on alignment of their research with REMADE Institute R&D priorities (50%), whether they contributed to a peer review selected paper (25%) for the conference and whether the candidate self-identified as belonging to group underrepresented in STEM (25%) as defined by NSF[1].

Notably, 72% of awardees comprised students pursuing master’s degrees, Ph.D. candidates, and postdoctoral associates, while 28% represented early career faculty, including assistant professors, research scientists, and a postdoctoral fellow. A noteworthy 68% of grant recipients contributed to peer-reviewed papers selected for presentation at the conference, highlighting their academic excellence. Additionally, 52% of awardees self-identified as belonging to underrepresented groups in STEM, underscoring the grant's commitment to diversity and inclusion.

The conference provided these researchers with a unique opportunity to delve into the latest advancements and methodologies in sustainable manufacturing. They engaged with global industry leaders and academic experts, fostering invaluable knowledge exchange, and paving the way for ongoing innovative research to solve these complex challenges. Researchers also attended project presentations and poster sessions in topics such as Enabling a Circular Economy through AI and Machine Learning, Mechanical & Chemical Recycling, Pathways to Net Zero Emissions, and Systems Analysis & Material Flows. Through their participation, researchers gained practical insights and tools to support their work, and drive the transition towards a Circular Economy in the U.S.

The conference proceedings have been published in a book, Dr. Nabil Nasr, ed., 2024, Technology Innovation for the Circular Economy: Recycling, Remanufacturing, Design, Systems Analysis and Logistics, Wiley.
